Editor's Note
</p>
</td>
<td style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;vertical-align: bottom" valign="bottom" width="33%">

<td height="28" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-top: 2px solid #353535; border-right: 2px solid #353535; border-radius: 0 10px 0 0; font-size: 0px;" valign="bottom">

<tr>
<td style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;vertical-align: top" valign="top">
<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: separate" width="100%">
<tr>
<td class="editors_note" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding: 0px 40px 16px 40px; border-left: 2px solid #353535; border-right: 2px solid #353535; border-bottom: 2px solid #353535; border-collapse: collapse; border-radius: 0px 0px 10px 10px;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<div>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Good morning. </strong>Anyone else feel like all of their friends are getting married this year? My web traffic this week has consisted exclusively of Google Flights, Zola registries, and hotel booking sites.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">At least I’m in good company. Nearly 2.5 million weddings are expected to happen in 2022, according to the trade group the Wedding Report. That’d be the highest total since 1984.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Wait, what the heck was going on in 1984? The NYT hopped in a time machine and <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2022/02/04/fashion/weddings/weddings-surge-1984.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">revealed</a> how wedding frequency can reflect wider social and economic trends.</p>
<ul style="line-height:22px">
<li>
<span><strong>More weddings are a sign of a strong economy. </strong></span><span>Couples get hitched when they have disposable income and believe they can financially support a family. The US economy in 1984 was growing at a faster rate than in any subsequent year until…2021.</span>
</li>
<li>
<span><strong>They’re also a sign of changing social norms. </strong></span><span>President Ronald Reagan’s brand of conservatism promoted “traditional family values,” TV shows like </span><span><em>Family Ties </em></span><span>did the same, and former hippies emerged from their communes and embraced monogamy.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">This year’s wedding boom is probably less indicative of a broader cultural reset and more due to mass cancellations in 2020–2021, but nonetheless it’ll be closely watched by demographers for whether it produces a much-needed baby boom. The US population increased just 0.1% last year, the slowest population growth on record.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;font-family:flood-std, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;font-size:16px;font-weight:500">—Neal Freyman</p>
</div>
</div>
</td>

<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;word-break: keep-all; word-wrap: normal; text-align: center; text-transform: uppercase; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 16px; line-height: 18px; color: #353535; padding: 0px; margin: 0px;">
Q&A
</p>
</td>
<td width="33%" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt">
<div style="text-align: center; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #2b9295, #1c7ff2); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;">

<tr class="">
<td class="column" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#353535!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="#">Icebreakers with...Quibi founder Jeffrey Katzenberg
</a>
</h1>
<img alt="An illustration of Jeffrey Katzenberg in boxing gloves" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/e88215dba3ff1e033c964226058958aea83f8fc0-1500x1000.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
<span class="source" style="display:inline-block;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px"><small><em>Dianna "Mick" McDougall</em></small></span>
<div>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">A year ago Jeffrey Katzenberg was seeing stars—and not quite like he’s used to.The well-known Hollywood power broker took a blow to the chin with the sale of Quibi, the short-form mobile media company he founded in 2018. The service shuttered just six months after launch and didn’t quite spark the video revolution that he and CEO Meg Whitman had hoped. Today its remnants reside with Roku.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">What do you do when you’re knocked down? Get back up, of course. Katzenberg regrouped with WndrCo, his well-funded investment firm that birthed Quibi, and got back to business investing in others’ companies. Among his latest ventures is a digital security company called Aura, led by founder and CEO Hari Ravichandran. Morning Brew spoke to Katzenberg about his latest project and lessons learned from Quibi’s flameout.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Jeffrey, you’re a Hollywood guy, known for your time running Walt Disney Studios and DreamWorks Animation. You last founded Quibi, a short-lived, short-form mobile media company. What on earth do you have to do with cybersecurity?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">About five years ago I sold DreamWorks [to NBCUniversal]. The moment after shaking hands to do that, my next thought was, if I were 20 years old today, what would I be doing? I would be in digital technology. The innovation, the entrepreneurial activity…I thought what would happen would be 10x what it was.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">So I reached out and found excellent partners, two ex-Dropboxers, and started WndrCo. They’re twice as smart as me and half my age. They homed in on the wide path of digital and cyber technology. So it has been a place of interest and investment for us from the beginning. Aura is a consumer opportunity. It’s a subscription service, marketing...so many of the things I find very familiar.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>“Consumer” is as broad as it gets. How do you limit your purview?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">There is simply not a facet of our daily lives that in the next 10 years is not going to be, in significant ways, impacted and transformed and improved through digital technology. Ordering food on a menu? How 20th century. Or maybe second century. Driving, how we get to work, how we communicate and collaborate. Not evolutionary, but revolutionary. So when you have a bottomless well of curiosity, it’s a world of extraordinary opportunity.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>When we last spoke, you were about to debut Quibi. What did you learn from its failure?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">I couldn’t be prouder of what we built and delivered. The big idea of a next generation of film narrative, longform stories in quick bites. The content that was made, the talent that contributed to it, the studios that made it. They exceeded my expectations.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">But I am humbled by its failure. It clearly did not have a product–market fit. We can argue about, was it the product, was it the market at the time we launched, or was it never to be a fit? But we do get up everyday and take a little TV with us and have in-between moments. Will it never be a product–market fit? I’m not sure.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">So I’m humbled. In life I believe the greatest lessons you learn are from your mistakes and misses and not your successes. Trying to follow your exact path on your next success usually doesn’t lead to success. But the learnings from failure are powerful. I am humbled, but not humiliated by it, because I am proud of what we did.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>Why is Katzenberg so bullish on Aura? <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/02/05/what-s-next-for-jeffrey-katzenberg?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Read our full interview here</a>.</em></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>This interview has been edited and condensed for clarity.</em></p>
</div>


</div>
</td>
</tr>

<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#353535!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/02/04/make-it-work-an-ode-to-hitting-to-all-fields?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}">Hitting to all fields
</a>
</h1>
<a style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/02/04/make-it-work-an-ode-to-hitting-to-all-fields?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" class=""><img alt="Make it work image " style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/7b6de1bb891bb0dd9e289abb0a591582a5da30e6-1503x603.png?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a><div>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>Each week, our workplace whisperer Shane Loughnane answers a reader-submitted question about problems at work. Anything nagging at you? <a href="https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24880110.2715963/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77Bb6753cbd?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Ask Shane here</a>.</em></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><a href="https://www.masslive.com/news/2022/02/the-republicans-sportswriting-legend-garry-brown-dies-at-90.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Garry Brown</a>, legendary Western Mass sports columnist, passed away this week following a career that spanned more than seven decades. I grew up reading his signature feature, “Hitting to All Fields,” written as a stream-of-consciousness sampling of the world of sports. In lieu of our typical Q&A layout, today’s format is an ode to Brown and his unique style.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Just sitting and wondering how many winning Super Bowl squares I’ll need in order to make up for January’s sack of my 401(k).</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>On the bright side, President’s Day is just around the corner. Three-day weekend, anyone?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Don’t forget to let your manager know you’re observing National Haiku Month. If that email can’t be written in 17 syllables, it should probably stay in the drafts until March.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Honk if you remember commuting (and honking?) in pre-Covid rush hour traffic. Yeah, I don’t miss it either.</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">News item: Energage<em> </em>announced the recipients of its 2022 Top USA Workplace awards this week. Check <a href="https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20220201005074/en/Energage-Announces-Recipients-of-2022-Top-Workplaces-USA-National-Award?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">here</a> to see if your recently renovated home office made the cut.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Add Milton’s red stapler to my list of all-time favorite office supplies.</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Must-see TV: my upcoming remake of the movie <em>Groundhog Day</em>, where I finally manage to solve a Wordle in fewer than three tries.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Speaking of groundhogs, let’s hear it for ol’ Phil. Proof that with a little hard work (once a year, to be exact), you can still reach the height of your profession without an advanced degree or a TikTok account.</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">You’re getting old if you watched George Costanza sink his teeth into the Penske file.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>In case you missed it: <em>The new hire who showed up is not the same person we interviewed</em> (<a href="https://www.askamanager.org/2022/01/the-new-hire-who-showed-up-is-not-the-same-person-we-interviewed.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Ask a Manager</a>). </strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">There’ll never be another Tom Brady.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>We’ll get back to our typical format next week. If you have an issue at your workplace, <a href="https://morningbrewdaily.typeform.com/to/fY1CGzyY?utm_source=morning_brew&typeform-source=www.google.com" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">share your concerns</a> and maybe we’ll reply to you in a future Brew</em>.</p>

<td align="left" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 10px 0px; word-break: break-word;">
<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;color: #353535; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 22px; table-layout: auto; width: 100%; border: none;" width="100%">
<tr>
<td width="33%" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt">
<div style="text-align: center; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #ffe62e 25%, #0f9046); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;">

<td style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border: 2px solid #353535; background: white; margin: 0px; padding: 10px;">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;word-break: keep-all; word-wrap: normal; text-align: center; text-transform: uppercase; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 16px; line-height: 18px; color: #353535; padding: 0px; margin: 0px;">
ANALYSIS
</p>
</td>
<td width="33%" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt">
<div style="text-align: center; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #2b9295, #1c7ff2); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;">
 
</div>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="">
<td class="column" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#353535!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/02/04/why-alphabet-split-its-stock?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}">Why Alphabet split its stock
</a>
</h1>
<a style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/02/04/why-alphabet-split-its-stock?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" class=""><img alt="Google logo broken up into many pieces" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/3afdcc116cf47af766655e1d81ebf060d3c228e1-1500x1000.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
<span class="source" style="display:inline-block;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px"><small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small></span>
</a><div>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">It was a wild week for the stock market, so we won’t be disappointed if you missed a bit of juicy news:</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Google parent company Alphabet said it would <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2022/02/01/google-parent-alphabet-announces-20-for-1-stock-split.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">split its stock</a> 20–1. That means come July, Alphabet shareholders will receive 19 more shares for every one that they own. It <em>doesn’t</em> mean they’ll be 20x richer—the price of the stock they hold will drop a proportional amount. If the stock split were to happen today, Alphabet’s share price would fall from $2,865 to $143.</p>
<h2 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">Why does it matter?</h2>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">In many ways, it doesn’t. A stock split does not change the value of the company. It’s simply a way to increase the number of shares outstanding.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Think of it like slicing a pizza. At a share price of almost $3,000, Alphabet’s slices were as wide as a monstrosity you’d scarf down in Adams Morgan at 3am. With the stock split, it’s cutting company ownership into more snackable portions. But, in the end, the pizza isn’t growing—there are just more slices to be shared.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">So why do it? Well, that’s kinda the point: By making the slices of its company smaller, it hopes that more people will look at them and say, “Well I guess <em>one </em>couldn’t hurt.” Alphabet said the goal of the stock split is to attract more small-time investors who might have been intimidated by buying in at such a steep share price.</p>
<ul style="line-height:22px"><li><span>Only 27 other stocks in the S&P 500 have share prices above $500 besides Alphabet.</span></li></ul>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">However, lowering your share price to make it more enticing runs counterpoint to current investing trends. Robinhood, Fidelity, Schwab, and other brokerages all allow investors to buy <em>fractional </em>shares of companies, which means you don’t have to shell out nearly $3,000 to acquire one share of Alphabet. These days, you can buy in dollar amounts—so $500 would get you 0.17 shares of Alphabet, or $2 would get you…much less. But you could still do it.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Yet there’s evidence this bit of corporate inception can <a href="https://www.reuters.com/business/retail-consumer/alphabet-latest-megacap-split-its-stock-may-trigger-retail-buying-2022-02-02/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">be effective</a>. To see why, let’s look at what happened when two other tech giants, Tesla and Apple, split their stock recently.</p>
<ul style="line-height:22px">
<li><span>When Apple split its stock 4–1 in July 2020, retail investors upped their purchases from $150 million per week to nearly $1 billion, according to Vanda Research.</span></li>
<li><span>When Tesla split its stock 5–1 in August 2020, retail investing jumped from $30–$40 million/week to $700 million.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">There may be another play for Alphabet here—and that is to pad its resume for inclusion in the iconic Dow Jones Industrial Average. Because the Dow is weighted by share price (an antiquated system, to be sure), Alphabet at its current price would overwhelm all of the companies. It would become the Alphabet Industrial Average. At $247, it becomes a much more attractive candidate for the Dow.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Final fun fact:</strong> According to Newton’s third law of motion, a company can also execute a <em>reverse</em> stock split. You don’t want to own a company that attempts such a maneuver. The goal of a reverse stock split is to boost a company’s share price, perhaps because it’s gotten so small that it’s vulnerable to being delisted on an exchange. The parent company of MoviePass (RIP) conducted a 250–1 reverse stock split in 2018 when its shares had plummeted to eight cents a piece. Needless to say, it didn’t work out.—<em>NF</em></p>
</div>

style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding: 0px 40px 16px 40px; border-left: 2px solid #353535; border-right: 2px solid #353535; border-bottom: 2px solid #353535; border-collapse: collapse; border-radius: 0px 0px 10px 10px;\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv style=\"font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGood morning. \u003c/strong\u003eAnyone else feel like all of their friends are getting married this year? My web traffic this week has consisted exclusively of Google Flights, Zola registries, and hotel booking sites.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eAt least I’m in good company. Nearly 2.5 million weddings are expected to happen in 2022, according to the trade group the Wedding Report. That’d be the highest total since 1984.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWait, what the heck was going on in 1984? The NYT hopped in a time machine and \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2022/02/04/fashion/weddings/weddings-surge-1984.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003erevealed\u003c/a\u003e how wedding frequency can reflect wider social and economic trends.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"line-height:22px\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMore weddings are a sign of a strong economy. \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eCouples get hitched when they have disposable income and believe they can financially support a family. The US economy in 1984 was growing at a faster rate than in any subsequent year until…2021.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThey’re also a sign of changing social norms. \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003ePresident Ronald Reagan’s brand of conservatism promoted “traditional family values,” TV shows like \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cem\u003eFamily Ties \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003edid the same, and former hippies emerged from their communes and embraced monogamy.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThis year’s wedding boom is probably less indicative of a broader cultural reset and more due to mass cancellations in 2020–2021, but nonetheless it’ll be closely watched by demographers for whether it produces a much-needed baby boom. The US population increased just 0.1% last year, the slowest population growth on record.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;font-family:flood-std, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;font-size:16px;font-weight:500\"\u003e—Neal Freyman\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n{if profile.signup_time \u003c time(\"-45 days\")}\n{if ! padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv style=\"font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;\"\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003e\n\u003ca target=\"_blank\" style=\"color:#353535!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\" href=\"#\"\u003eIcebreakers with...Quibi founder Jeffrey Katzenberg\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"An illustration of Jeffrey Katzenberg in boxing gloves\" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/e88215dba3ff1e033c964226058958aea83f8fc0-1500x1000.jpg?w=670\u0026q=70\u0026auto=format\"\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"source\" style=\"display:inline-block;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px\"\u003e\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eDianna \"Mick\" McDougall\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eA year ago Jeffrey Katzenberg was seeing stars—and not quite like he’s used to.The well-known Hollywood power broker took a blow to the chin with the sale of Quibi, the short-form mobile media company he founded in 2018. The service shuttered just six months after launch and didn’t quite spark the video revolution that he and CEO Meg Whitman had hoped. Today its remnants reside with Roku.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWhat do you do when you’re knocked down? Get back up, of course. Katzenberg regrouped with WndrCo, his well-funded investment firm that birthed Quibi, and got back to business investing in others’ companies. Among his latest ventures is a digital security company called Aura, led by founder and CEO Hari Ravichandran. Morning Brew spoke to Katzenberg about his latest project and lessons learned from Quibi’s flameout.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eJeffrey, you’re a Hollywood guy, known for your time running Walt Disney Studios and DreamWorks Animation. You last founded Quibi, a short-lived, short-form mobile media company. What on earth do you have to do with cybersecurity?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eAbout five years ago I sold DreamWorks [to NBCUniversal]. The moment after shaking hands to do that, my next thought was, if I were 20 years old today, what would I be doing? I would be in digital technology. The innovation, the entrepreneurial activity…I thought what would happen would be 10x what it was.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eSo I reached out and found excellent partners, two ex-Dropboxers, and started WndrCo. They’re twice as smart as me and half my age. They homed in on the wide path of digital and cyber technology. So it has been a place of interest and investment for us from the beginning. Aura is a consumer opportunity. It’s a subscription service, marketing...so many of the things I find very familiar.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e“Consumer” is as broad as it gets. How do you limit your purview?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThere is simply not a facet of our daily lives that in the next 10 years is not going to be, in significant ways, impacted and transformed and improved through digital technology. Ordering food on a menu? How 20th century. Or maybe second century. Driving, how we get to work, how we communicate and collaborate. Not evolutionary, but revolutionary. So when you have a bottomless well of curiosity, it’s a world of extraordinary opportunity.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhen we last spoke, you were about to debut Quibi. What did you learn from its failure?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eI couldn’t be prouder of what we built and delivered. The big idea of a next generation of film narrative, longform stories in quick bites. The content that was made, the talent that contributed to it, the studios that made it. They exceeded my expectations.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eBut I am humbled by its failure. It clearly did not have a product–market fit. We can argue about, was it the product, was it the market at the time we launched, or was it never to be a fit? But we do get up everyday and take a little TV with us and have in-between moments. Will it never be a product–market fit? I’m not sure.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eSo I’m humbled. In life I believe the greatest lessons you learn are from your mistakes and misses and not your successes. Trying to follow your exact path on your next success usually doesn’t lead to success. But the learnings from failure are powerful. I am humbled, but not humiliated by it, because I am proud of what we did.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eWhy is Katzenberg so bullish on Aura? \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/02/05/what-s-next-for-jeffrey-katzenberg?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\u0026mid={{md5(profile.email)}}\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eRead our full interview here\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eThis interview has been edited and condensed for clarity.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003c!-- END SOCIAL LINKS - --\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c!-- END ARTICLE --\u003e\n\u003c!-- SPONSORED SECTION --\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd align=\"left\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; Anything nagging at you? \u003ca href=\"https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24880110.2715963/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77Bb6753cbd?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\u0026mid={{md5(profile.email)}}\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eAsk Shane here\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.masslive.com/news/2022/02/the-republicans-sportswriting-legend-garry-brown-dies-at-90.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eGarry Brown\u003c/a\u003e, legendary Western Mass sports columnist, passed away this week following a career that spanned more than seven decades. I grew up reading his signature feature, “Hitting to All Fields,” written as a stream-of-consciousness sampling of the world of sports. In lieu of our typical Q\u0026A layout, today’s format is an ode to Brown and his unique style.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eJust sitting and wondering how many winning Super Bowl squares I’ll need in order to make up for January’s sack of my 401(k).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eOn the bright side, President’s Day is just around the corner. Three-day weekend, anyone?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eDon’t forget to let your manager know you’re observing National Haiku Month. If that email can’t be written in 17 syllables, it should probably stay in the drafts until March.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHonk if you remember commuting (and honking?) in pre-Covid rush hour traffic. Yeah, I don’t miss it either.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eNews item: Energage\u003cem\u003e \u003c/em\u003eannounced the recipients of its 2022 Top USA Workplace awards this week. Check \u003ca href=\"https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20220201005074/en/Energage-Announces-Recipients-of-2022-Top-Workplaces-USA-National-Award?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ehere\u003c/a\u003e to see if your recently renovated home office made the cut.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAdd Milton’s red stapler to my list of all-time favorite office supplies.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eMust-see TV: my upcoming remake of the movie \u003cem\u003eGroundhog Day\u003c/em\u003e, where I finally manage to solve a Wordle in fewer than three tries.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSpeaking of groundhogs, let’s hear it for ol’ Phil. Proof that with a little hard work (once a year, to be exact), you can still reach the height of your profession without an advanced degree or a TikTok account.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eYou’re getting old if you watched George Costanza sink his teeth into the Penske file.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIn case you missed it: \u003cem\u003eThe new hire who showed up is not the same person we interviewed\u003c/em\u003e (\u003ca href=\"https://www.askamanager.org/2022/01/the-new-hire-who-showed-up-is-not-the-same-person-we-interviewed.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eAsk a Manager\u003c/a\u003e). \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThere’ll never be another Tom Brady.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eWe’ll get back to our typical format next week. padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv style=\"font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;\"\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003e\n\u003ca target=\"_blank\" style=\"color:#353535!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\" href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/02/04/why-alphabet-split-its-stock?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\u0026mid={{md5(profile.email)}}\"\u003eWhy Alphabet split its stock\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003ca style=\"text-decoration:none; border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/02/04/why-alphabet-split-its-stock?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\u0026mid={{md5(profile.email)}}\" class=\"\"\u003e\u003cimg alt=\"Google logo broken up into many pieces\" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/3afdcc116cf47af766655e1d81ebf060d3c228e1-1500x1000.jpg?w=670\u0026q=70\u0026auto=format\"\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"source\" style=\"display:inline-block;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px\"\u003e\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eFrancis Scialabba\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIt was a wild week for the stock market, so we won’t be disappointed if you missed a bit of juicy news:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eGoogle parent company Alphabet said it would \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2022/02/01/google-parent-alphabet-announces-20-for-1-stock-split.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esplit its stock\u003c/a\u003e 20–1. That means come July, Alphabet shareholders will receive 19 more shares for every one that they own. It \u003cem\u003edoesn’t\u003c/em\u003e mean they’ll be 20x richer—the price of the stock they hold will drop a proportional amount. If the stock split were to happen today, Alphabet’s share price would fall from $2,865 to $143.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003eWhy does it matter?\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIn many ways, it doesn’t. A stock split does not change the value of the company. It’s simply a way to increase the number of shares outstanding.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThink of it like slicing a pizza. At a share price of almost $3,000, Alphabet’s slices were as wide as a monstrosity you’d scarf down in Adams Morgan at 3am. With the stock split, it’s cutting company ownership into more snackable portions. But, in the end, the pizza isn’t growing—there are just more slices to be shared.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eSo why do it? Well, that’s kinda the point: By making the slices of its company smaller, it hopes that more people will look at them and say, “Well I guess \u003cem\u003eone \u003c/em\u003ecouldn’t hurt.” Alphabet said the goal of the stock split is to attract more small-time investors who might have been intimidated by buying in at such a steep share price.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan\u003eOnly 27 other stocks in the S\u0026P 500 have share prices above $500 besides Alphabet.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eHowever, lowering your share price to make it more enticing runs counterpoint to current investing trends. Robinhood, Fidelity, Schwab, and other brokerages all allow investors to buy \u003cem\u003efractional \u003c/em\u003eshares of companies, which means you don’t have to shell out nearly $3,000 to acquire one share of Alphabet. These days, you can buy in dollar amounts—so $500 would get you 0.17 shares of Alphabet, or $2 would get you…much less. But you could still do it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eYet there’s evidence this bit of corporate inception can \u003ca href=\"https://www.reuters.com/business/retail-consumer/alphabet-latest-megacap-split-its-stock-may-trigger-retail-buying-2022-02-02/?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ebe effective\u003c/a\u003e. To see why, let’s look at what happened when two other tech giants, Tesla and Apple, split their stock recently.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"line-height:22px\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan\u003eWhen Apple split its stock 4–1 in July 2020, retail investors upped their purchases from $150 million per week to nearly $1 billion, according to Vanda Research.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cspan\u003eWhen Tesla split its stock 5–1 in August 2020, retail investing jumped from $30–$40 million/week to $700 million.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThere may be another play for Alphabet here—and that is to pad its resume for inclusion in the iconic Dow Jones Industrial Average. Because the Dow is weighted by share price (an antiquated system, to be sure), Alphabet at its current price would overwhelm all of the companies. It would become the Alphabet Industrial Average. At $247, it becomes a much more attractive candidate for the Dow.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eFinal fun fact:\u003c/strong\u003e According to Newton’s third law of motion, a company can also execute a \u003cem\u003ereverse\u003c/em\u003e stock split. You don’t want to own a company that attempts such a maneuver. The goal of a reverse stock split is to boost a company’s share price, perhaps because it’s gotten so small that it’s vulnerable to being delisted on an exchange. The parent company of MoviePass (RIP) conducted a 250–1 reverse stock split in 2018 when its shares had plummeted to eight cents a piece. Needless to say, it didn’t work out.—\u003cem\u003eNF\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: collapse\" width=\"100%\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding-top: 12px\"\u003e\n\u003ca rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer.php?u=https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/02/04/why-alphabet-split-its-stock\u0026utm_source=facebook_share\" class=\"\"\u003e\u003cimg style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: inline-block;
